text: A response to the article: I don't think it is accurate to link the drawbacks of Haskell's IO model (i.e. monads) to its type system. There are other ways of introducing IO to statically typed pure functional languages, including (as I've mentioned before) the actor model, which Elm implements, and which people seem to find easier.

elements.text: A response to the article: I don't think it is accurate to link the drawbacks of Haskell's IO model (i.e. monads) to its type system. There are other ways of introducing IO to statically typed pure functional languages, including (as I've mentioned before) the actor model, which Elm implements, and which people seem to find easier.

text: Fair point, Thanks. So this rigidness is not because of type system, because of something else.

elements.text: Fair point, Thanks. So this rigidness is not because of type system, because of something else.

text:
<@UE6EFEPTQ> - your argument is compelling. Let me add some nuance so you can see where I'm coming from as well:

> Personally, for my own goal of programming for non-techies,

I have a similar goal, but while I used to be concerned with someone's *first few experiences* of programming, I am now not so worried if they need to spend a reasonable amount of time (similar the amount of time people spend to learn Excel) to get up to speed. I am now more concerned with the problem of *normal people wanting to make small changes to large app that the use in a reasonable amount of time* (which will take longer if they are not yet used to programming at all or in this new system).

> The real world

The is a common strategy, trying to argue that a language feature or paradigm is "closer to reality" somehow. For example, Alan Kay talks about how objects are great because they are like biological cells and cells are able to create great complexity, emerging from simple parts. That convinced me in the past, but I am now skeptical of those claims, because "like reality" is not an end in and of itself. The goal, I believe, is the *comprehensibility of large systems* and nature seems to resist comprehension, or at least be quite difficult to comprehend, a la quantum mechanics.

> has state,

There are a few different ways to handle state in FP. My preferred way is the original FRP, now called DCTP (denotative continuous time programming). I think it's truly beautiful,  but it also took me months to fully grasp, so it's hard to communicate why.

Here's one way to understand it: it's like directly plopping the equations from your physics textbook into your text editor and then you have gravity. It's like math. No IO Monad required.

>  visible everywhere,

Firstly, state in the "real world" is not visible everywhere... unless you're some sort of superhero with x-ray vision... if so, that's a different discussion... :wink:

Secondly, *composibiliy* is a really important property, and it's hindered by global state.

> and real "types" are in the eye of the beholder.

This is a fascinating claim. Types are a really difficult thing to pin down and define. In my head, they've always had to do with the *shape* of some data. I have an essay on it, here. <https://medium.com/@stevekrouse/types-are-shapes-d6af1e83192f>

If we use this metaphor to think through what you said, I think you would be incorrect because shapes are objective in reality. You simply cannot fit a round peg into a square hole.

I guess you could say that "round" and "square" are human-defined concepts... but if you want different concepts I guess you could make your own types and type classes

text: <@UCKRZS3DZ> Yeah I'd attribute the "rigidness" (or perhaps, "friction") to the *model* of IO that Haskell makes available.

text: Imperative languages typically provide an imperative model of IO, also known as "anything goes", which makes anything possible, but good program architecture hard.

elements.text: Imperative languages typically provide an imperative model of IO, also known as "anything goes", which makes anything possible, but good program architecture hard.

text:
<@UCKRZS3DZ>

> Yeah I'd attribute the "rigidness" (or perhaps, "friction")

I strongly suspect (and hope) this rigidness is simply an experience-level thing, not a language-level thing. I currently am working on making a Haskell-like language feel very fluid.

Here's the vision: instead of telling you when you're *wrong*, types should be aids that help you "figure out what's possible*. To get a physical sense of what I mean, imagine a toy kit with toys of different shapes and being able to feel with your hands which toys can go where based on their shapes and how they slide into one and other - or get jammed.

> to the *model* of IO that Haskell makes available.

The IO monad is not truly Haskell, where I'm defining *true Haskell* to be a "denotative" language. Original FRP (DCTP) is. Or at least it's much closer. This is a really subtle and beautiful point that I'm obsessed with. <http://conal.net/blog/posts/can-functional-programming-be-liberated-from-the-von-neumann-paradigm>

This is the wrong question. The right question is: given better abstractions than IO with complicated types, how can I wrangle these types to do what I want?

text:
<@UCGAK10LS>

> I'm assuming when you say the IO monad is not "true Haskell", you mean the operational semantics isn't?

I'm talking about denotative semantics. The IO Monad doesn't have any denotative *meaning*. This is a really subtle point so I apologize for lobbying it into a group discussion.

>  I'm not sure what the significance of bringing this to light is.

Most people think IO is a necessary abstraction, but I disagree. I think it can be pushed to the *implementation level*. This is a very nuanced point but I think it's super important in these kinds of conversations about the merits of Haskell. Reading and re-reading this point a couple dozen times was how I got to this perspective: <http://conal.net/blog/posts/can-functional-programming-be-liberated-from-the-von-neumann-paradigm>

text: I agree the IO monad is rubbish. As I mentioned, I think Elm does it better (by working on messages instead of recreating imperative instruction sequences). I've tried and failed before to gain any insight from Conal. I think the fact that few people truly understand (and can apply) what he's talking about suggests that it may just be obtuse gospel built around fragments of insight (as harsh as that judgement may be).

But it seems that FRP can't be used for communication between two independent machines. It feels like you have to go discrete messaging, no way around it.

So there must be a box larger than FRP.

text:
> the problem of normal people wanting to make small changes to large app that the use in a reasonable amount of time

Sounds good to me. I'm up for that challenge!


> "like reality" is not an end in and of itself.

As far as I'm concerned, "like reality" is absolutely what this is about: "programming is casting spells over reality", even if that reality is generated by machines. It's about the perception of the person doing the programming being met well enough.


> The goal, I believe, is the *comprehensibility of large systems* and nature seems to resist comprehension

With good structuring, you can comprehend a large system by looking only at a small subsystem. And you only need to comprehend the nature you care about to the degree it's useful.


> There are a few different ways to handle state in FP. My preferred way is the original FRP, now called DCTP (denotative continuous time programming). I think it's truly beautiful,  but it also took me months to fully grasp, so it's hard to communicate why.

I think "in FP" is the problem: you need to give state a first class status, then add FP! I don't like streams or event streams or anything that forces natural models of reality into a theoretical straitjacket. My mother doesn't see a stream of events around her: she sees changing state!


> state in the "real world" is not visible everywhere

My mother would disagree - everywhere she looks and walks is a whole bunch of state that was there yesterday and will probably be there tomorrow, with a few changes perhaps..


> It's like math. No IO Monad required.

I agree that "No IO Monad required" is an excellent goal! As is being well-ordered like mathematical abstractions.


> *composability* is a really important property, and it's hindered by global state.

Not if you structure your global state - the web is composed very well, thanks!



> Types are a really difficult thing to pin down and define. In my head, they've always had to do with the *shape* of some data. I have an essay on it.. If we use this metaphor to think through what you said, I think you would be incorrect because shapes are objective in reality. You simply cannot fit a round peg into a square hole.  I guess you could say that "round" and "square" are human-defined concepts... but if you want different concepts I guess you could make your own types and type classes

I'm in the duck typing camp: if you can hit a small glass bottle into the round hole using a square peg as a hammer, you're good to go..

I think shape===type, too, in fact: if I see some data shape as this type and you see that shape as that type, who cares?

Sounds good to me. I'm up for that challenge!

and nature seems to resist comprehension

I think "in FP" is the problem: you need to give state a first class status, then add FP! I don't like streams or event streams or anything that forces natural models of reality into a theoretical straitjacket. My mother doesn't see a stream of events around her: she sees changing state!
state in the "real world" is not visible everywhere
My mother would disagree - everywhere she looks and walks is a whole bunch of state that was there yesterday and will probably be there tomorrow, with a few changes perhaps..
It's like math. No IO Monad required.
I agree that "No IO Monad required" is an excellent goal! As is being well-ordered like mathematical abstractions.
composability
is a really important property, and it's hindered by global state.
Not if you structure your global state - the web is composed very well, thanks!
Types are a really difficult thing to pin down and define. In my head, they've always had to do with the
shape

of some data. I have an essay on it.. If we use this metaphor to think through what you said, I think you would be incorrect because shapes are objective in reality. You simply cannot fit a round peg into a square hole.  I guess you could say that "round" and "square" are human-defined concepts... but if you want different concepts I guess you could make your own types and type classes

I'm in the duck typing camp: if you can hit a small glass bottle into the round hole using a square peg as a hammer, you're good to go..

I think shape===type, too, in fact: if I see some data shape as this type and you see that shape as that type, who cares?

text:
Ok, I tried it out. Immediate feature request ideas: navigating by page/screen rather than line. And search. Both will help manage large files.

It would also be good to integrate with something like `ctags` somehow, so that one can jump to definitions from function calls. But that would require introducing some sort of notion of a cursor.. Or mouse support. Yeah, a mouse would be good.

It would also be good to integrate with something like
ctags

text:
Have you been doing this in the context of your documentation ideas? Particularly I'm thinking of your idea to allow non-authors to contribute documentation: <https://futureprogramming.slack.com/archives/C5U3SEW6A/p1542220709063000>.

Overall, this feels like a great 'toy' (<http://www.paulgraham.com/organic.html>) that can grow into something ambitious.

attachments.fallback:
[November 14th, 2018 10:38 AM] felix.kohlgrueber: That's an interesting discussion! I'd be neat if more people would collaborate on documentation, and as <@U5STGTB3J> pointed out, novices to a project are especially important as collaborators.
I wonder if more people would edit documentation if it wasn't owned by the project's owner. Think about having wikipedia-like editing right within your documentation. Especially if I'm new to a project, I'm always afraid to screw up other people's documentation by writing something stupid. I wonder if knowing that the next regular guy who reads my changes could easily improve or correct them would lower the bar to start collaborating.
Another option could be to include comments into each documentation page. People are used to providing feedback if they can, so they would probably point out a lot of issues that could then be used by maintainers to improve documentation.
Using current tools (IRC, github issues / PRs) all of this is possible already, but I think that making it easier and integrating it better into the documentation itself could make a huge difference.
attachments.text:

Especially if I'm new to a project, I'm always afraid to screw up other people's documentation by writing something stupid. I wonder if knowing that the next regular guy who reads my changes could easily improve or correct them would lower the bar to start collaborating.
Another option could be to include comments into each documentation page. People are used to providing feedback if they can, so they would probably point out a lot of issues that could then be used by maintainers to improve documentation.
Using current tools (IRC, github issues / PRs) all of this is possible already, but I think that making it easier and integrating it better into the documentation itself could make a huge difference.

elements.text: Have you been doing this in the context of your documentation ideas? Particularly I'm thinking of your idea to allow non-authors to contribute documentation:

.

Overall, this feels like a great 'toy' (
) that can grow into something ambitious.

text:
New experiment... <@UCUSW7WVD> and I just chatted for the first time. It was quite fun! And we recorded it! I'm curious if anyone watches it and finds value. If so, maybe we'll do it again, and maybe I'll convince others to go on the air with me in casual chats. Thanks Kartik for going out on a limb and trying this with me. Really amazing to finally chat! <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DuMdDXCMDk0>

For reference on what we talked about, here are the notes I took from the convo:
```
* first computer experience when he was 18
* studying engineering in India in college
* before he found computers, he was going to do MBA and be business guy
* UT Austin PhD in computer systems (compiler and micro architecture)
  * wanted to re-think *all* the assumptions from the ground up based on what we know about compilers
  * as well as the other direction, redesigning compilers based on ISA architectures
  * it was all very theoretical because nobody was going to use it, because backwards-compatibility has force. who's going to invest in a new processor?
  * we're in a x86-mono culture
* and then Bay area ever since
* my idea of convervatism is don't change things because we don't know why they work: Chesterton's fence. You can't tear it down until you tell me why it was erected in the first place.
  * threading the needle: refactoring a legacy code base with tests and refactoring slowly, incrementalism
* legacy is code no person on your team understands
* he's not an IDE programmer, just a text editor guy... love how he says this outright up front
* all the things you do to see if your code works after you right it is lost unless you encode as a test
* joined Google in 2010 and was disheartening to see how the meat was made
* the code at Google was shit despite great engineers, because it was passed through hands
* law of software: suckage increases over time
* all langauges (python 3, perl 6) go through period of backwards incompatible changes
* big course corrections are a sign of a big mistake
* also applies to countries: USA, Rome
  * coleen mccoulogh historical fiction novels about rome: the first man in Rome
* but the decay in software is not entropy
  * it's more like complexity creep, which is quite similar to law creep
* the deepness in the sky - one of his favorite sci fi books with real programmers
* code runs on the trunk but there should be lot more forking activity....
```

elements.text: New experiment...

and I just chatted for the first time. It was quite fun! And we recorded it! I'm curious if anyone watches it and finds value. If so, maybe we'll do it again, and maybe I'll convince others to go on the air with me in casual chats. Thanks Kartik for going out on a limb and trying this with me. Really amazing to finally chat!
For reference on what we talked about, here are the notes I took from the convo:

* first computer experience when he was 18
* studying engineering in India in college
* before he found computers, he was going to do MBA and be business guy
* UT Austin PhD in computer systems (compiler and micro architecture)
  * wanted to re-think *all* the assumptions from the ground up based on what we know about compilers
  * as well as the other direction, redesigning compilers based on ISA architectures
  * it was all very theoretical because nobody was going to use it, because backwards-compatibility has force. who's going to invest in a new processor?
  * we're in a x86-mono culture
* and then Bay area ever since
* my idea of convervatism is don't change things because we don't know why they work: Chesterton's fence. You can't tear it down until you tell me why it was erected in the first place.
  * threading the needle: refactoring a legacy code base with tests and refactoring slowly, incrementalism
* legacy is code no person on your team understands
* he's not an IDE programmer, just a text editor guy... love how he says this outright up front
* all the things you do to see if your code works after you right it is lost unless you encode as a test
* joined Google in 2010 and was disheartening to see how the meat was made
* the code at Google was shit despite great engineers, because it was passed through hands
* law of software: suckage increases over time
* all langauges (python 3, perl 6) go through period of backwards incompatible changes
* big course corrections are a sign of a big mistake
* also applies to countries: USA, Rome
  * coleen mccoulogh historical fiction novels about rome: the first man in Rome
* but the decay in software is not entropy
  * it's more like complexity creep, which is quite similar to law creep
* the deepness in the sky - one of his favorite sci fi books with real programmers
* code runs on the trunk but there should be lot more forking activity....

text: The passage I mentioned at the end: <http://akkartik.name/post/deepness>

elements.text: The passage I mentioned at the end:

text:
Responses to <@UE6EFEPTQ>... this lack of nesting is getting hard!

>> "like reality" is not an end in and of itself.

> As far as I'm concerned, "like reality" is absolutely what this is about: "programming is casting spells over reality", even if that reality is generated by machines. It's about the perception of the person doing the programming being met well enough.

It's a two-sided problem as described in this Bret Victor photo: <http://worrydream.com/ABriefRantOnTheFutureOfInteractionDesign/Images/Tool2.png>

I'm arguing that the "part that fits the person" doesn't need to be that closely related to the "part that fits the problem". We have some flexibility here.

> I don't like streams or event streams or anything that forces natural models of reality into a theoretical straitjacket. My mother doesn't see a stream of events around her: she sees changing state!

Your mother also doesn't see the equations for the laws of physics but they are the best way to *model* reality (that we have discovered so far). They are the best tool for the job for understanding and predicting reality. That's the key -- not to simply defer to what people already have in their brains but to build a powerful tool to extend their capabilities, which will require them to grow what's in their brains to meet the "tool" halfway.

>> state in the "real world" is not visible everywhere

> My mother would disagree - everywhere she looks and walks is a whole bunch of state that was there yesterday and will probably be there tomorrow, with a few changes perhaps..

There's a ton of state that is hidden to us all. For example, the other night I felt like I was getting sick. I didn't know. It was all hidden inside me. Turns out it was just a blip. I have no idea why. Reality is quite opaque for a lot of questions. Software has the potential to be *infinitely* understandable and *infinitely* customizable* - why settle for the meagerness of reality?

>> *composability* is a really important property, and it's hindered by global state.

> Not if you structure your global state - the web is composed very well, thanks!

This is only because the web as global state is just static pages. The web doesn't have dynamic global state, where one web page can modify another page's state. That's maintained by ugly HTTP plumbing code on the side.

As far as I'm concerned, "like reality" is absolutely what this is about: "programming is casting spells over reality", even if that reality is generated by machines. It's about the perception of the person doing the programming being met well enough.
It's a two-sided problem as described in this Bret Victor photo:
I'm arguing that the "part that fits the person" doesn't need to be that closely related to the "part that fits the problem". We have some flexibility here.
I don't like streams or event streams or anything that forces natural models of reality into a theoretical straitjacket. My mother doesn't see a stream of events around her: she sees changing state!
Your mother also doesn't see the equations for the laws of physics but they are the best way to
model

reality (that we have discovered so far). They are the best tool for the job for understanding and predicting reality. That's the key -- not to simply defer to what people already have in their brains but to build a powerful tool to extend their capabilities, which will require them to grow what's in their brains to meet the "tool" halfway.
> state in the "real world" is not visible everywhere
My mother would disagree - everywhere she looks and walks is a whole bunch of state that was there yesterday and will probably be there tomorrow, with a few changes perhaps..

There's a ton of state that is hidden to us all. For example, the other night I felt like I was getting sick. I didn't know. It was all hidden inside me. Turns out it was just a blip. I have no idea why. Reality is quite opaque for a lot of questions. Software has the potential to be
infinitely
understandable and
infinitely
customizable* - why settle for the meagerness of reality?
composability
is a really important property, and it's hindered by global state.
Not if you structure your global state - the web is composed very well, thanks!

This is only because the web as global state is just static pages. The web doesn't have dynamic global state, where one web page can modify another page's state. That's maintained by ugly HTTP plumbing code on the side.
